name: The Ricky Gervais Guide to: The English

transcript.content: "To be born English, is to win first prize in the lottery of life." So said Cecil Rhodes, one of the grandfathers of British Imperialism. At it's height, the British Empire ruled over one quarter of the World's population. And consequently exported Englishness to the furthest reaches of the globe. But what is Englishness? Is it stiff upper lips and fair play? Village greens and tea and crumpets? And who are the English? Are we defined by a shared heritage, a common set of beliefs, by the language of Shakespeare? Or in a multicultural modern age, when more languages are spoken in England than in any other country in Europe, do we need to develop a new view of what it means to be English? To discuss and define the nature and characteristics of the English, I'm joined by Stephen Merchant, graduate of the University of Warwick, and award winning writer.
Thank you for having me.
And Karl Pilkington, a man who, by his own admission didn't go to school, has no qualifications...
Mention the head, talk about the head!
I'm gonna mention it, I'm just trying to get to the point that he's not qualified in anything or really-
True
...Has no authority in any subject, hasn't got the right to-
Talk about the head!
AND WHO'S KNOWN THE WORLD OVER AS A MAN WHO'S GOT A HEAD LIKE A FUCKING ORANGE! Cuuuuuuuun--!
Alright!
Intro music

I think one thing that's very English, is harping back and whinging combined. People saying "Oh, England used to be better in my day" or "England was better when I was a kid, England was better in the 50s" or whatever. Karl, do you think England is better now? Are you happier now? Than you were when you were a kid?
Do you feel that life was better in, say, the 1950s?
I don't know, I wasn't around.
So you understand what it was like in those days? You've seen happy days.

I don't know. People always say, don't they? Old people always say "Oh it was a better life in the 50s." It's like, yeah, it was for them. Of course it was for them, they're old now. Being old isn't great, is it? So you're just happy with your lot? I suppose I was happier starting about... 1984?
Steve laughs
Right
A so specific year?
Why was that?
Just I was free and happy.
How old were you?
I don't know... (mumbles while trying to remember)
He's just counting on his fingers now...
Twelve.
Right, okay.
And it was just good.
So the happiest days of your life were between the age of 12 and 13?
Yeah, it was good. I had the world ahead of me...
Little did you know your hair was going to fall out and you're going to whinge Every. Minute. Of the day.
Had me bike. I liked messing about me bike. You had your mates, I had a pet magpie.
So you were probably the teenager that you'd eventually hate.
Probably.
Were you a good lad? Law abiding?

I wasn't bad. I just sort of... you know, pottered about. I mean when people talk about what was on the telly back then, I don't have that much memory of it, because I was always out. I was always playing out.
What were you doing when you're out?
Just playing about. Just like on a bike or...
Just riding in a circle, endlessly... Through blizzards, rain, sleet, hail...
I tell you! I loved it!
I never seemed to be in. When everyone always goes "Where were you when Band Aid was happening? I was always out on my bike. And everything was like-
Like Ewan McGregor!

Our memory is always sort of like coming in for some orange and looking at the telly, seeing Princess Diana's getting married, and me mum says "Have you seen this?" And going "No, I'm going out on me bike." I was always doing that.
Steve & Ricky laugh
This is why you don't know anything, because you never stopped!
Yeah, but this is what being a kid's about! That's what I mean, being free.
But all the information you have, Karl, is as though, you've gleamed at as you raced by on a bike. (laughs)
As if every information you have-
The hair- The hair blowing in the wind...
"Karl, your hair will blow out one day!"  "Oh, don't talk stupid, Mam!"
So yeah, 12 to 13 was good.
But you see...
And it was all downhill from then, was it?
13, you're teenager then, aren't you? Life got tough.
Yeah. How did it get tough?
Just straight away when I was 13, my mom was like "Oh, it's your 13th birthday, you're a teenager now."
Alright

And she gave us a quid to go and get a cake to celebrate it. Went to the supermarket, got a cake, and I just thought "I don't like the look of this! Don't like the look of the way the future is here."
Ricky & Steve laughs
On his 13th birthday!
When you were buying a cake, what did you see at the supermarket that--
Just- It kind of like... I don't know, I suddenly felt grown up. I didn't like it.
But I think you're always about 58, really, with your outlook.
Well, yeah, my mom always said I was old. She said I was an old baby. She said I could frown before I could walk.
Ricky chuckles
Always had a bit of a worried look on my face. Didn't say much, just always listened. My eyes moved about more than I did. Sat there looking around. Looking stressed.
(laughs) "Me eyes moved about more than I did!" Oh dear! Couldn't walk.
"Well, I can't walk but I'm trying to get a bit of movement in my face." It's a workout. A baby workout. Alright babies! Well, if you can't walk, what about your face? Let your face do the walking.
It sounds like that horror film... It sounds like 'Pilkinton's Baby'.
Yeah.
Just you lying there in your cot.
I didn't like all the stuff that's set up for you. Me mum tried to send me to... a nursery. I said "No I'm not having this!"
Ricky laughs
(laughs) Just like that! At three, "I'm not having this!"
I said, when I'm older and I've got to go, I'll go. But let's leave out this bit. She said alright.
(laughs) I love the fact that he could reason with her!
He's three years old with a pipe. She's going... he goes: "I think not, Mum."
Ricky sniffs
Steve laughs

I mean, kids don't play out, do they? Kids are-- You know- Parents are scared to let the kids play out. And that's why the streets are dangerous now. Because no one's playing out on the streets. Whereas when I was a kid, everyone was out on the streets. The streets were safer because there was more people knocking about.
Right
Let the kids play out.
It must be like a constant-- Like a Lowry painting, his front garden, do you know what I mean?
Just loads of people, just walking around.
There was never any problems. I was sort of taken away by some fella.
(laughs) What?!
Woah woah woah!
No, I was playing about in the garden.
Yeah?

But me dad's mate Tony, he did tiling with him. He drove past, and he saw me looking a bit fed up, so he just leant over, picked me up, took me to the pub. Now the thing is, there wasn't panic! People weren't going "Oh god, where's Karl gone?!"
He's out.
Just-
How old were you?
He's down in the pub. "He's four years old!" "Yeah"
"He's down at the pub with Tony, probably playing darts."
Ricky sniffs
I was about three or four.
Sorry! So some float drives by, who happens to be a friend of your dad, thinks that baby looks grumpy...
Yeah
...I'm taking him down to the pub.
[~3 mins of missing transcription]
[~3 mins of missing transcription]
See, now, my image of an Englishman is...is essentially that cliched one. It is, I think, Hugh Grant.
So you're modern, you're straight away modern now.
All I would say it's either mixed between Hugh Grant and Roger Moore when he was James Bond.

You see, that's another small percentage of Englishness that sort of annoys me. Those people that think they're James Bond, they think they can buy a suit and read GQ and they're suave and sophisticated and they get cars they can't afford or what they basically do. The people who think they're James Bond, all they do is work in a bank, come home and flick through GQ at the advert, looking at people wearing watches and aftershave. Who wears aftershave?
Do you wear after shave Karl?
Normally, after shave is the sort of thing that other people buy me. It's like underpants. Underpants, tea towels, and sort of aftershave and that...other people buy me.
Whose buying you tea towels?
Me mam.
Right, okay.

Now she turns up, she's got Brillo pads and stuff. I've got loads of them. I keep saying to her, "I don't need any of this," but she always brings a box full of stuff. Brillo pads, tea towels, underpants. The underpants - the size hasn't gone up since I was 14, but, that's, I can rely on her for that.
So do you not have anything in your life which you would think of as being gentlemanly? Do you ever dress smartly? What about suits?
I bought one suit that time when you invited me to the Baftas. That's the only suit. I wore it for the Baftas.
I wore it for one other thing. I haven't wore it since. I don't feel comfortable. It's not me.
It'd be a lovely advert wouldn't it him with a suit on going, "I haven't wore it since." Karl Pilkington hasn't wore it since.
No. I don't like going to them.
I agree.
I mean, even though you know them, they don't give you any time when you're there, do they? Just they don't know whether you're there or not. They're on cloud nine. They don't know who's around.
Yeah with them it's all me me, me, isn't it?
What do they like?
You don't even get to make a speech, do you?

Although I know you were annoyed Steve. Steve doesn't like to part with money. I don't know what the politically correct term is. Stingy can't be, I mean, it's fucking mean. And if he ever has to spend out on like a wedding gift to someone who's known all his life, they look down the list and they find things under £25. Then if he bothers spending that much, he's furious when someone and usher goes, Just stick it there.

Oh, it drives me insane. Well, firstly, I'm annoyed about the wedding list. I don't know when that's come along, because I don't know why I can't just bring maybe something I've made at home. Why is there got to be a list of stuff?
What bride, what newly married bride doesn't want a pair of homemade clogs?
Exactly.
Do you know what I mean?
And then you arrive there and it's just, "oh, thanks very much, stick it on the table." But - saying that I think people very much appreciate you being at their wedding.
No.
No, they do.
They remember if you were there.
No, they don't.
They do.
You don't get invited to any, cause you haven't got any mates.
All right, I know enough people. Everyone's getting married, but they're always in the middle of nowhere.

That annoys me when people say, come to our wedding. Yeah, we're in Greece. Well, no, down the road. I might make it down the road for the reception. Go to quit. What, you want me to book a holiday and come to your wedding?
[~3 mins of missing transcription]
[~3 mins of missing transcription]
Can't even bother to put your trousers on in the summer....
Ricky laughs
I know! I know! Mine's got an elasticated waistband on them. They're still fiddling with braces and buttons.
Yeah.
So anyway, yeah, that's what I like about Italians and that. There's a lot of...
So you want to be Italian because when you're old, you can sit outside a cafe and get more respect than you do here?
Yeah. Look at the old people in this country. They never look happy do they, really? Most of the time, when you see them walking around, they go to pot. No one's keeping an eye on them.

Well, it's an important thing isn't it? My er... My mum, this is when she was about 60-65 and there was a neighbour, who was erm.... 85-90 and again, completely alone and my mum used to go there every day. "Do you want any shopping doing?" right. She was good for her. She was like her witness in the world, you know, to her existence. But I remember calling her once and she's come back. I said, "What've you been doing?" She went, "Oh, I've been round so and so's." I went, "All right". She went, "She won't die, Rick."
Steve laughs
Like, she's helping her but she's thinking "This is getting silly now. You were meant to go years ago, here...."
Ricky laughs
Well that's the problem. If you get pally with an old person, you could be stuck with them for years!

And having to do stuff, you know, that's what you don't want to do is it? You meet an old fellow and then you've got to start popping in his sort of piles or whatever. When he can't do him himself, you know, what do you do? If you're.....
It depends how friendly you are, though. I mean, I'm just talking about someone you meet at the bus stop as opposed to popping their piles back in.
Ricky bursts out in laughter
How does that happen? Jesus...
Just the ones on the estate I grew up on. As soon as you got to a certain age, it was Mrs. Knowles who went mental. One day she seemed fine, next day she was chucking cans in everyone's garden.
Ricky laughs
You could just hear her coming.
Ricky laughs
Which was weird. Actually now you brought up weird people. There was a fella called Shorts-Man, right.
Ricky bursts out in laughter
He's so pedestrian. I love the fact....
Shorts-Man wore some shorts?
Now what I like...
Yeah, he did. But they were really short. They were that sort where it's almost pointless having them on.
What do you mean?

You know like shorts now, for blokes, to go up to your knees, don't they? There's no chance. There's no accident happening there. There's nothing going to pop out. But Shorts-man. He liked it. He liked the fact that happened. And he used to walk with big strides to sort of help the chance along. So that he knew, with the big strides and the short shorts.
Yeah
They were gonna pop out.
Did you ever see it pop out?
Yeah.
Why were you looking at his shorts?
Just because it was like playing Buckaroo. It was like, when are they going to pop out?
Ricky & Steve laugh
It's just what happened.
So... Right. But Shorts-Man, so he was an exhibitionist. He liked... he obviously wanted people to see his Veg.
Yeah. And they were out more than they were in. I mean, they had a tan.
Ricky bursts out in laughter
Right, now the thing is, what we like in England, I think we like that. We like local characters.
The eccentric.
Yeah
Yeah. Eccentric that's very British. Eccentric. Yeah.
And I'm glad I grew up down there with all them people...
So am i.
...because they were interesting.

Well, there is a certain mindset about the great English, certainly the older English people. I mean, my Grandparents are you know. My Grandfather died recently, but they're amazing, kind of eccentric, very English, seemingly no friends from what I can identify. I don't know if this is unique to them or true of a lot of English people. Older people, terrified of what the neighbours might say, always did that thing of...
Steve begins to whisper
Speaking like that in case somebody..
Yeah.
...Jack's in next door
Yeah.
Like the neighbours are constantly listening in.
Ricky laughs
Yeah, yeah.

They've got glasses against the wall. They're constantly listening to what my Gran's got to say. They had about three teeth between them. It was extraordinary. My grandfather had a plate of false teeth during the war that had a wooden palate, a wooden upper palate...
Wow
...with teeth on it. And those teeth slowly fell off during the course of the years..
Got woodworm?
...Never got replaced, so they sort of invited to Sunday roast and they would wake up at six in the morning to put the beef on and they wouldn't have it till six in the evening.
Ricky laughs
They would cook it. The biggest compliment you could have if you made some food for my Gran, if it was some beef would be; "oh you, so lovely this, you this so tender, you can suck it away!"
Ricky laughs
If you could suck your Sunday roast through a straw. She was happy.
Well yeah she didn't have any teeth.
Right exactly. Basically they got to about the age of 60 or something and it was as though they were just waiting to die.
Ricky chuckles
It was strange. And they lived for another my grandfather lived for at least another 25 years.
Ricky starts laughing

So he must have been gutted. But my father, when my father needed a winter coat, a big heavy winter coat, and he was thinking of buying one and my Gran said "No don't worry about that, Ron, you can have your father's winter coat." And he said, "Well, he's still alive. What do you mean? He needs his winter coat." She went, "No, he'll be dead soon. Just don't.... silly to waste it. Silly to waste it. Just wait." My father must have been waiting ten years for that winter coat.
I love the fact he waited.
Steve laughs
Of course he waited!
You can see where Steve got it from!
Of course he did.
Stupid. I'm waiting, now.
Ricky laughs
Steve, you must be freezing.
I am cold but i tell you, it's a lovely coat.
In English society, traditionally and now, is manners.
Steve makes a noise of agreement
I mean, obviously manners change...
Etiquette.
....but what is etiquette? What is good manners? I think that a lot of that has been lost.
Well, I was thinking the other day, have you ever heard of the finishing school, Karl?
Yeah. Yeah, of course.
No.
Do you know that the idea is that the sort of gentrified ladies, after they've finished their education, they would go to finishing school where they would literally
Be taught you know how to...
What knives and forks, walking with a book on your head, just things like what to say.
I mean, that's preposterous.

It's like a year of being Eliza Doolittle, isn't it? Don't put your elbows on the table. You start from outwards going inwards with cutlery. You eat soup, the spoon goes away. But there's things like the fork, you're never meant to face those prongs up. So you either stab your peas or.
[~3 mins of missing transcription]
[~3 mins of missing transcription]
Oh, dear.

Do you think there's a big difference, Karl, between the Englishman of yesteryear, who didn't complain. I mean, he just got on with things. He might have whinched about the weather and the like, but he just got on with things.
He carried an umbrella.
Yeah, nowadays People are getting their Prozac and antidepressants. And goin into therapy.

And he Kept out of stuff as well, as war and so and so. And so they're coming this way. If they come over here, give them a slap. Well, why do we get involved now in everything. Thoughts on that Karl?

Uhhh It's news now, innit? Sometimes I think, don't tell me. Don't want to know. Just get on with it. Whoever's job that is, get on with it. Why am I being told about it. when I've got a problem with my job. No one else knows. No one else helps me out and goes, Well, I've got an opinion for him. This might help him. No one helps me, but I'm being bombarded by everyone else's hassle. They love talking, actually. That's what the English do, talking, but they never finalized it. They love just being in the meeting room talking, saying, yeah, we could do this, we could do that. I'm the only one in that room not getting paid. Everyone else is on a wage. I'm there looking at me watch, thinking, I've been here for an hour and nothing has been sorted. They're looking, thinking, we can drag this out for another half hour. Get to lunch. That's what annoys me. They're all sat there, just pushing bullshit around the room like dung beetles.
(laughing)

I'm sick of it, And that's what the English do. It's a shame because I don't think we used to be like that. I wish everybody just sort of kept themselves more like certain animals do. Just get on with it.
Like what? what animals? What animals keep to themselves?
Any animals keep to themselves.
Like what?
Loads of things.
What animals keep themselves?
Badgers.
Why do they keep to themselves?
I don't know. Whenever you see them, you're sort of wandering about a roadside. They're on their own. There not sort of in pairs.
What are they doin?
I don't know. Most of the time they're dead. I've seen more dead badgers than live ones. I've never seen a live badger.
I don't know what his point was.
And that's why there one alone, and two getting on with it. I love it.
It started with some kind of poetic analogy. I don't know what that was.
I just uhhh-

Oh, God, I like this thing. The Englishman I knew growing up was when you hit a certain age, when you hit like, manhood or puberty at 13,14,15, you have to start showing your metal then. The most important thing then was to- the worst thing to be growing up was gay. That was like you couldn't be gay. It couldn't be gay, anything but gay. And then you had to be hard to be tough. I remember when I first started going to pubs, right? So, I don't know, say 18, you walk into a toilet, the urinals, and the first thing everyone did was fart and gob, that was it. Right. If you couldn't do that, then you get funny looks. You go in the urinal and they'd look at you. Oh, sorry. It was all about being a man.
[~3 mins of missing transcription]
But I-- What's the problem here? What am I meant to be worrying about?
Well, you've got, you've got bow and arrows.
Yeah.

They're amazing. They're heavy. They're, they're-- your arms right-- they've got, they've got trained bowman. They're skilled. The most skilled sort of marksmen-- uh, uh soldiers in the country. Someone comes along, goes, "Don't worry about that. Here's a crossbow. Just pop it in, pull it back (crossbow noise). Deadly. Deadly, quick. Anyone can use it." So now you've got anyone with a crossbow killing people.
Women. Children.
Anyone can use it. So the Europeans, they're going crazy. Old William Tell and his uh, they-- they're shooting apples off heads.
Yeah.
Right? But we didn't-- we resisted it because we thought it was, y'know, un-Christian and cheating to kill without skill. What do you think of that?
But where were the-- where were the actual bows an' that being made? Because that's the thing, innit? The, the, the-- the company who's making 'em, they just want to get  out to a big market.
Brilliant.

That's-- that's what they do now with the iPod and everything. It's not about people wanting more music than ever before. That's not the case. It's about having it, having the accessory. And if the bow and arrow, was like sold as this, y'know. "Light to carry. For all the family." That's-- that's how it would have happened. That's where it's all about.
"Ye new bow and arrow. From Ronco."
But what-- what do you think the problem is?
Yeah, but you're not quite getting Ricky's point. His point is the idea of there being sort of rules and fair play and etiquette in war. The objective is to kill the enemy.
I don't-- I don't think that's the place. I don't think war an' that is a place to start getting all uppity about someone cheating or having a better system.
Oh. Really? You think all fair in love and war, do you?
Yeah, definitely. It's just about winners.
Right, but there are rules isn't there?
No, not in a war, there isn't rules.
So what about things like the Geneva Convention? It's the understanding that even if we're entering into a war, theoretically there's a set of agreement about the rules.
It's good for both sides, isn't it? Fair play has got to come into everything.

What's extraordinary about the idea of English fair play is y'know, famously y'know, the approach during the First World War. That we would sort of walk up out of the trenches on to No Man's Land and sort of politely march at a slow, steady pace across--
I know.
--towards the enemy, and then, I mean, we were just being machine gunned down. I mean it was absurd.
Well-- I know we were fodder. It was fodder to use up some of their bullets. I mean it was crazy.
But I mean it's madness. But in a way, it's-- it's the gentry who are leading us, seeing y'know, the average Tommy as a sort of-- as cannon fodder. I mean it's--

Of course, of course. And you know, you got to realize that most of those people didn't want to be there. Most of them didn't even understand it. I mean, and if you think of the First and Second y'know, they were just wars, y'know? But um I, I just-- I can't-- I just can't imagine what it would be like.
How would you think, do you think Karl, in a war situation? You've seen all those films of the uh--
I mean, that's the one they had uh, a-- a knock about and stuff, didn't they? They took, y'know the game of football--
In No Man's Land, yeah. Christmas Day.
But who-- who took a football there? (Ricky and Steve laugh) Ehh, if I was on the front line, I would not be getting out the rulebook. I can tell you that much. I'd be going mental.
Are you saying there should be some rules or no rules?
[~3 mins of missing transcription]
"It was going around burning people..."

"Doesn't matter, we shouldn't have killed the last one. It's the last one!" and that's what it would be like. "You should have saved it. You should have captured it and put it in a cage so we can all look at it."
"There's no point. You couldn't have bred anyway with the last one."
"Was it definitely the last one?"
"Well, you're saying it was the last one. I'm not bothered either way."
So you think that there were dragons?
Well, what are we celebrating them?

Well, it could be a metaphor, a dragon slayer. It could be a bad thing amongst us, it could be a foreign threat, it could be things that threaten - it could be anything. It's not to be taken literally, is it?
But the real legend of George was that he was a figure who stood up for Christianity. Have you ever done anything brave?
There was a kid at school who used to have epileptic fits a lot and the teachers always say, if it happens, grab his tongue, and I sort of had to go at that once.
His what?
His tongue.
His tongue?
Yeah.
What did he have a tong for? To pick stuff up? What do you mean? The tongue?
His tongue, in his mouth.
Oh his tongue...
Oh his tongue. Right, go on.
They used to say, if he starts doing it, grab his tongue, and I sort of had to go at that once, and it wasn't nice.
How did you grab it, you grabbed his tongue did you?
Well, I tried to it's like grabbing a slug, and plus his mouth is going up and down, you think "he's going to have my hand here". So you sort of to do that thing where you go...
So you - you're trying to grab hold  of the kid's tongue? Yeah. And he was...

He's throwing himself all over the place. It was in a physics lesson. I sort of had a go and then I thought, "this isn't happening". So I just sort of kept putting my hand in like I'm having a go, but in my head I was going, "I'm not going to get hold of it".
What you could have used is a pair of tongs.

Well, firstly, I don't see why this is brave. Kids have an epileptic fit and you're just supposed to help him out. I don't know why that's bravery, but even given that the fact that you were thinking more about yourself in that situation than this other kid, you were thinking, I'll make it look like a helping, but I'm not really. And yet there's this kid having an epileptic fit.
Well, I did at the beginning.
Doesn't that sum you up, karl - selfish.
No, it doesn't, because no one else was having a go. At least I did try and grab it at one point.
You weren't doing anything. You were just making it look like you were.
Have you ever tried to grab a tongue? He's like chasing the chicken. It's murder. And after a while it wears you out. And it was weird anyway, because...
How long was he doing it for?!
I don't know!
Wearing him out after hours of chasing this kid's tongue.
I love the idea "have you ever tried grabbing a tongue?" is a valid question.
I love that he's annoyed. He's annoyed that this poor kid's having an epileptic fit.
What was your technique? Were you trying to grab it just with...
Just with your thumb and your whats-it finger, like a pincher thing. But it was - because his mouth going down...
Was he shouting or just..?
No just throwing himself around.
So that's your one attempt at bravery.
Well hang on a minute. Let me just think... [inaudible]
Was the time you were chased by a bee and you scored a goal.
I forgot about that.

That isn't really bravery is it, as you were running away from a bee, and the ball happen to hit your foot and go in. That count is bravery? I love it when he goes up to the pearly gates and God goes "well, have you done the act of courage?" - I pretended to grab a tongue. A what? a tongue? A tongue. Yeah. I got chased by a bee, scored a goal. It doesn't count as brave at all.
Well what have you ever done?
Well it's a good question.

I thought of something then, when I was a kid on the beach there was a baby. Like a toddler, I was about twelve and they were out - their little boat had gone out, the mother missed it and they were miles out and the mother was sort of distraught and I swam out, and I was a good swimmer then and I pulled it in, right, and she bought me a box of chocolates.
It's not enough. Is it?
What?!
It's not enough, a box of chocolates. I'd have been furious.
Really?
I would have wanted a lot more.
I didn't expect anything.

No it was like when I found that old lady's person I sent it back to her and she sent me a little thank you note with nothing, no cash, nothing - I was furious I thought. Come on. I could have kept that purse I sent it back to you I need more than a little thank you note.

I didn't expect anything - I was sort of - I wasn't even particularly proud of myself but I just thought - well, I could just do it. I mean, if it happened now I'd go "what's in it for me, I've just eaten". I go, "Is that your kids? They're miles away!". I've got less brave, I'm more scared of the world.  The things I used to do - jump off sheds, I used to jump down flights of stairs to see if I could do it, walk along wall - you know all those things that kids do - and um, you lose your nerve I think. Apparently if you haven't bungee jumped by your thirties you never will.
Really?
Yeah I think it's the sensible gene kicks in.
I'm pretty sensible.
Yeah, you think well this is not worth dying for. Don't do it. You know.
Yeah.
But uhh...

I think having glasses prevents me from doing a lot of things. No, seriously because it's hard to be brave with glasses because if I stepped into the middle of a fight and there's people being bullied and I stepped in - if my glasses come off that's it.
(laughing) I love that.

Now I'm just being bullied as well. I'm also blind, so I'm just crawling... It's very hard to strike fear into your opponents when you're crawling around on the floor looking for your frames going "don't step don't - tread lightly, tread lightly" that's two hundred quid there.
Oh god, I love that when you took up judo and you think you overheard the judo instructor say, "just knock his glasses off".
"Just knock his glasses off".
But why are you - who are you Woody Allen? What are you doing, in this scenario? Why are you stepping into the dojo wearing a pair of glasses anyway?
How am I supposed to do judo without...?
They come off immediately.
But what am I supposed to do? Not do any form of martial art because of the glasses?
I don't know. Actually, I haven't thought about that.
Exactly. This is the problem, isn't it? People don't think that you'd never see boxers with glasses.
Well, of course you don't.
Right, exactly. So I got no kind of athletic role models in that way, except Dennis Taylor.
(laughing) Oh god. A man with glasses. Me and my classes.
I'll tell you this. I could write a book on the difficulties of having glasses.
But I [inaudible] it's completely affected your life hasn't it?
Of course it has.
Everything you do.
Of course it has.
Fashion.

Fashion, sport, dancing, motion. Can't go in the mosh pit. I've always wanted to jump on the stage and take the shot off and then jump back in and everyone catches you and you sort of sway along on top of everyone's hands. Can't do it. The glasses will come flying off.
But how do you swim in the sea?

I'd have to hand them to the singer and then... I was in India recently. I went to Goa and I've got myself a pair of prescription goggles. Could not believe my life. It's revolutionized my swimming experience.
All right.
Goggles, which have got the same lenses in as my glasses.
All right, that's good.

Went in there, literally. And they're pricey as well. We're in the water. Within seconds, giant wave had come over and it was crazy - it was like Rio all over again. It ripped off both my trunks and goggles. They went flying off my head. I can only grab one of them.
My trunks have never come off. Maybe once I dived in, they come down a little bit.
They came loose and they slipped down, thus revealing penis. Goggles came off.
I reckon you're shorts, man. I think you've been doing it on purpose.
You know how most swimmer...
Tie your shorts up Steve. Nah, I'm just going to sea - but if they come off? If they come off then you might see something.
You know, most swimming goggles would float. My prescription is so dense that they just sunk straight to the bottom.

If I should die, think only this of me, that there's some corner of a foreign field that is forever England. There shall be in that rich earth a richer dust concealed a dust whom England bore, shaped, made aware, gave once her flowers to love her ways to roam a body of England's breathing English air, washed by the rivers, blessed by sons of home and think this heart all evil shed away a pulse in the eternal mind no less. Give somewhere back the thoughts by England given her sights and sounds dreams happy as a day and laughter learnt ff friends and gentleness in hearts of peace under an English heaven.
Rupert Brook. The Soldier. What an amazing poem that is.
Yes, it's a shame you read it, though.
Ricky laughs.
Thanks for listening to the Ricky Gervais Guide to the English. That's it for a little while. Five in that series of guides to.
Plenty to be going on with.

Plenty to be going on with. There's also the rest of the back catalog as well, and we might do the odd free one, but we'll be back soon anyway with maybe another series of guides to who knows? Karl, thoughts? I've enjoyed this of you?
Yeah, my favorite ones. I like learning stuff, you know that. If I can learn somewhere and make a few quid, I'm happy.
Hmmmm.

Unlike the people who listen to this who are down two quid and have learned absolutely nothing. And what they have learned from you is total bollocks. So thanks. That's goodbye from me Ricky Gervais. Steven Merchant.
Goodbye.
And Karl Pilkinton.
Alright.

synopsis.description: Ricky rescued some kids on a boat, but was the reward sufficent?
Steve's glasses are a major hinderance.
Steve loses his prescription goggles in Goa (and his trunks).
Rupert Brook - The Soldier. Read by Ricky Gervais. Unfortunately.

trivia.description: Band Aid was the collective name of a charity supergroup featuring mainly British and Irish musicians and recording artists.

Long Way Round (LWR) is a British television series and book documenting the 19,000-mile (31,000 km) journey of Ewan McGregor and Charley Boorman from London to New York City on motorcycles. They travelled eastwards through Europe and Asia, flew to Alaska, and continued by road to New York.
